conclusion: Determine the radius r_max of a droplet just before it separates from the nozzle.
The droplet separates when the gravitational force on the droplet is equal to the surface tension force at the neck of the droplet.
Calculate the volume V of the droplet using the formula for the volume of a sphere: V = (4/3)πr^3.
Determine the mass m of the droplet as the product of its volume and the density ρ of the water: m = ρV = ρ(4/3)πr^3.
Calculate the gravitational force F_g on the droplet: F_g = mg = ρ(4/3)πr^3g.
Determine the surface area A of the droplet as the surface area of a sphere: A = 4πr^2.
Calculate the surface tension force F_σ at the neck of the droplet as the product of the surface tension σ and the circumference of the neck: F_σ = σ * 2πr.
Set the gravitational force equal to the surface tension force: ρ(4/3)πr^3g = σ * 2πr.
Simplify the equation by canceling out π and solving for r: ρ(4/3)r^3g = 2σr implies ρ(4/3)r^2g = 2σ implies r^2 = (3σ)/(2ρg).
Take the square root of both sides to solve for r: r = sqrt((3σ)/(2ρg)).
The radius r_max of the droplet just before it separates from the nozzle is sqrt((3σ)/(2ρg)).
